fields.description:
npm ci is much faster than npm install, but it uses a different predefined cache. So the user is asking if we can support new predefined cache for npm ci.

* {{npm ci}} makes builds reproducable, npm install with a node_modules cache can sometimes leave node_modules in a non deterministic state
* Fresh install of {{npm ci}} is faster than {{npm install}}
* {{npm ci}} with a npm cache and no node_modules is as fast as {{npm install}} with node_modules
fields.summary: Update npm install to npm ci and update predefine cache

fields.description: It seems that (sometimes?) the "X behind Y ahead" display of a feature branch is not updated in a  timely fashion: after rebasing a feature branch onto current master and force pushing to bitbucket the commits behind/ahead isn't updated (when build triggers are still running?)
fields.summary: feature branch status "X behind Y ahead" stale

fields.description: It has been reported that for at least one customer the 14-day value for the session is not being respected. Their session seems to disappear after a period of a few days, at most, and they need to log in again.
fields.summary: Some user sessions are being deleted prematurely

fields.description:
h2. Problem Definition
Currently, a user is able to add anyone on Bitbucket to _Users_ at "User and group access" on repository settings, which can cause an unexpected change.

!3268862999-Screenshot%202019-02-27%2016.21.50.png|thumbnail!

h2. Suggested Solution
Give an option to Team account which can avoid an accidental change such as:

* a config to restrict adding a non-Team member to Users access
* a config to enforce specifying access only by Group

h2. Workaround
Do not to give admin access to an uncontrollable number of people in your team, and make sure to specify access by Team group.\\
Besides, consider adding yourself as a watcher to be kept informed as to the state of this feature request moving forward. With that way, if our development team updates the ticket, you'll be notified via email.

h2. Notice
At the moment, we can't set an ETA for this feature to be released, since there's a number of factors that determine how our product team prioritizes new features.\\
You can learn more by reading [Implementation of New Features Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/implementation-of-new-features-policy-201294576.html].
fields.summary: Provide an option to avoid an unexpected change in repository access owned by Team account

fields.description:
Dear Bitbucket,

I'm using DeployHQ to automate deployments. I have pasted the SSH key generated by DeployHQ in my Bitbucket.

But it is not at all clear to me, which rights I have granted to DeployHQ with adding this SSH key. I'm guessing DeployHQ can now access all repositories (private and public) I have access to. And DeployHQ can make a commit or other changes via the SSH key under my name.

It would be great if a SSH key can be restricted:

# To ONE repository
# To be READONLY

Kind regards,\\
Mirco Babin
fields.summary: Explain Access Keys

fields.description:
As noted in Issues BCLOUD-6315 and BCLOUD-6589, relative URLs from markdown files were only fixed for the master branch.

I'm opening this because BCLOUD-6315 is marked resolved and BCLOUD-6589 is marked as a duplicate, so I don't think this aspect of the issue is actually being tracked.

This causes problems when trying to document your projects using multiple files.  First, it means that you have to merge to master before you can actually browse the documentation, which doesn't work well for large projects that have significant changes in branches which require different documentation.

Secondly, it can actually cause issues when you browse your branch's README.md file and then click a link to a sub page.  You'd think you're looking at the most recent version of that documentation in that branch, but it actually redirects you to master's version of that file.  This means you can be reading outdated documentation and thinking it's up to date, which causes frustration and confusion.
fields.summary: Relative URLs in Markdown Only Work in Master Branch

fields.description:
The builtin docker support in Bitbucket Pipelines does not support the swarm commands.

This is documented in https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/run-docker-commands-in-bitbucket-pipelines-879254331.html (although we should explicitly add the swarm command to the list).

We enable Docker inside Pipelines with certain constraints because of our security model, as listed in the documentation above.

We can investigate whether we can allow the swarm commands that allow deploying to a remote swarm (please vote and comment on your use-cases), however we will never be able to allow the daemon to join the cluster.

As a workaround note that it is possible to connect to your own Docker Daemon outside of Pipelines as mentioned in https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/run-docker-commands-in-bitbucket-pipelines-879254331.html _*Using an external Docker daemon*_ which will allow you to use docker swarm
fields.summary: docker swarm deploy not supported in Bitbucket Pipelines

fields.description:
Some feedback about the git auth proxy (which allows pushing back to your repository without any additional configuration) is that it opens an avenue for a potential attacker to commit back to a repository.  Under such a scenario, either a compromised Docker image or tool executed as part of the build process would attempt to commit back to a repository. Without user vigilance, such a change could go unnoticed.

Current mitigations include:

* Applying branch restrictions if there is concern about malicious parties attempting to write back to a repository.
* Cryptographic verification of untrusted third party tools (e.g verifying SHAs/digests of Docker images).
* Code review process to ensure untrusted tooling is not introduced into the pipeline.

As it stands, we would suggest verification of any tooling used in a build, as a poisoned tool can already 'steal' code, credentials stored in env vars, or write back from any system that has credentials available to do so.

For future work, we could make the git auth proxy 'opt out' via a configuration option in the bitbucket-pipelines.yml file. This would reduce risk of a tool being able to write back, without the need for configuring branch permissions.
fields.summary: Provide opt out option for the git auth proxy

fields.description:
Hello,

This issue is in regards to the new feature in BP that allows pushes back up to a repository without the need for authentication. I believe this creates a big security hole in what was (before this feature was introduced) a more secure system.

For example, consider a CI workflow where developers merge in PRs from outside developers. Aside from code reviews (which are subject to human error), there would be nothing stopping a malicious outside developer from writing a script that pushes code back up to the repository. Perhaps this could be prevented by locking down the repository with branch permissions (i.e. only allow code in via a PR merge), but then BP cannot use a bot account to do automated pushes.

It seems to me that the old system -- base64 encoding an SSH key -- while slightly inconvenient, was very secure. With the new HTTP pushing feature, that security is lost for a minor gain in convenience.

If I'm missing something here, I'd REALLY like to know what, because from my POV this is a big step backwards.

For reference, please see https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Bitbucket-Pipelines-articles/Pushing-back-to-your-repository/ba-p/958407?utm_campaign=mentions_comment&utm_content=topic&utm_medium=email&utm_source=atlcomm

(I have made several comments in the thread regarding this security hole. In particular, I was requesting further discussion, but got no response. I'm hoping raising the issue here will help.)

Thanks,

Ryan
fields.summary: Bitbucket Pipelines: "Pushing back to your repository" feature introduces security issue

fields.description:

fields.summary: Pipelines wont trigger

fields.description:
h3. Problem
Multiple Git repositories that all need the same deployment variables configured.

h3. Workaround / Current Solution
Do not use the deployment variables. Instead, configure global (e.g. team-wide) variables DEPLOY_TEST_URL, DEPLOY_PROD_URL and so on.

Implementing the workaround effectively makes the environment-specific configuration pointless. It will also break once there are flexible environments (#15362)

h3. Suggestion
Providing e.g. team-wide or project-wide deployment environments would not solve this issue. E.g. you might have 4/5 repositories within a project that need the same config, but one project that needs a different one. We would rather need something like a "deployment config" that can be declared repository-independent. And then, we would assign these configs to the individual projects.
fields.summary: Reuse deployment environments

fields.description:
Debugging Pipelines can be a pain, and the process normally looks something like:

# make a small change
# commit
# watch where the pipeline fails
# repeat

Local testing is possible (https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/debug-your-pipelines-locally-with-docker-838273569.html) but it's also a fairly involved process and it will never fully recreate the environment that Pipelines creates.

It would be _amazing_ if you could insert breakpoints into the yaml file, then interactively debug your environment through the browser.

Google Cloud Platform has done an excellent job of exposing an interactive shell through their browser, and it would be super handy (and unique to Bitbucket, I suspect) to have this sort of browser-shell enabling an interactive debugging experience inside a pipeline.
fields.summary: Interactive debugger for Pipelines

fields.description:
It used to be the case that, if you pushed a commit to bitbucket with a commit message that contained "fixes #N", with N being a valid ID of an issue in the same repository, the issue woule automatically get resolved as fixed, with a link in the issue to the commit mentioning it.

That no longer works.
fields.summary: REGRESSION: "Fixes #issueId" in commit message no longer automatically resolves the issue

fields.description:
When you comment to a pull request and uploaded an image with the image file name "*image (1).png*", the image is not uploading and it gives a broken image icon.

!558393402-PR_Image_name.png|thumbnail!

*Steps to reproduce*:

# Add comment on PR (open comment editor)
# Click on image icon → Drag image here dialogue opens
# Drag an image named "image (1).png"

h3. Expected Result
The image should show even if there's a "parentheses" in the image's file name.

h3. Actual Result
The image not showing and gives a broken image icon.

h3. Workaround
For now, make sure the image file name does not contain "parentheses".
fields.summary: Pull request Image Uploading

fields.description:
Some background:\\
I have the following commits in Sourcetree:

!2919319296-Slice%201.png|thumbnail!

Where "Yesterday" means February 20th.

Now, in Bitbucket:

In the Pull Request -> Commits tab the hours are shown correctly:

!3427139649-Slice%202.png|thumbnail!

In the Pull Request -> Activity tab the hour of this commit is also shown correctly:

!2085405146-Slice%203.png|thumbnail!

In the Pull Request list the "Last updated" hour(which is the hour of the Merge) is shown in a different format but still correctly:

!2484279235-Slice%206.png|thumbnail!

However in the Pull Request -> Activity tab the hours of Updating and Merging the Pull Request are shown in UTC:

!3742771000-Slice%204.png|thumbnail!\\
!4239379070-Slice%205.png|thumbnail!

PS. Don't mind the "X hours ago" texts, because I took these screenshots in no specific order and at different times. The tooltip shown after hovering is what matters.
fields.summary: Hours in Activity tab in Pull Requests shown in UTC

fields.description:
When the rate-limit is exceeded, the API returns a plain-text body that says:

"Rate limit for this resource has been exceeded"

Which is not valid JSON. Because the rest of the API is JSON, it makes sense to return the rate-limit error message in JSON format. Something like this:

{ "error": "Rate limit for this resource has been exceeded" }

would make it easier to handle errors in an automated fashion
fields.summary: API Rate Limit message should be in JSON

fields.description:
Hi there,

I've been able to skip CI using {{[skip ci]}}  when pushing to a master branch. Unfortunately, I haven't when pushing commits  (including {{[skip ci]}}) to a PR though (pipeline is triggered).

Am I doing anything wrong?

This is my  {{bitbucket-pipelines.yml}}:

{code}
image: python:3.6-alpine

pipelines:
  pull-requests:
    '*/*':
      - step:
          name: (make) test, build and publish qa artifacts
          deployment: staging
          caches:
            - pip
          script:
            - pip install --upgrade pip virtualenv
            - apk add --no-cache git make bash
            - NEXUS_USER=$NEXUS_USER NEXUS_PASSWORD=$NEXUS_PASSWORD make qa deploy
  branches:
    master:
      - step:
          name: (make) test, build and publish prod artifacts and tag git repo
          deployment: production
          caches:
            - pip
          script:
            - pip install --upgrade pip virtualenv
            - apk add --no-cache git make bash
            - NEXUS_USER=$NEXUS_USER NEXUS_PASSWORD=$NEXUS_PASSWORD make prod deploy tag
            - git push --tags
{code}

Thanks in advance,\\
Mario
fields.summary: [skip ci] (or alternatives) not working for pull-requests

fields.description:
Currently there is no way to mark that you have reviewed a PR up to a certain commit. This makes it hard to track what is changing between commits. The only way to currently do this is to {{Approve}} the commit which I think is sending mixed messages.

It would be great if you could mark a PR as {{Reviewed}} and then you get a similar message in the Activity tab to when you approve a commit. Something like {{{User} REVIEWED this pull request at commit {sha}. {link: see what has changed}}}.
fields.summary: Ability to mark a pull request as reviewed

The 2 endpoints below are not working using {UUID} parameter.

{code}

https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/teams/{UUID}/projects/

{code}

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If you enable 'New source browser experience', then open the 'Source' page of a repo in Bitbucket and select the button 'Clone', the option to 'copy to clipboard' the command for cloning is not working in Chrome.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open Chrome and log in to Bitbucket
# Go to Bitbucket Labs and make sure that 'New source browser experience is enabled'
# Open the 'Source' page of one of your repos
# Select the 'Clone' button at the top right of the page
# Select the 'copy to clipboard' button, next to the Git command for cloning

h3. Expected Results
The button should copy the command so you can paste it in command line

h3. Actual Results
The button does not work in Chrome

h3. Notes
I have tested with the latest version of Chrome, both Windows and Mac, also tried the Incognito Mode.\\
This button works as expected in Safari, Firefox and Microsoft Edge.
fields.summary: 'Copy to clipboard' option for clone command does not work in Chrome

fields.description:
In this message BCLOUD-6705 , it is advised not to use bookmarks but instead the evolve extension for PR.

evolve works fine with the topic extension (both are included in the same package hg-evolve).

When the experimental evolve support is activated (https://bitbucket.org/account/admin/features/), topics can already be used with Bitbucket and we would just need to be able to visualize them in the website.

We would only need few very simple modifications of few pages (in particular PR creation, PR summary, commit list, commit summary).

fields.description: My company turned on Two Factor to protect our Jira/Confluence accounts and our Bitbucket repos.  Annoyingly, when I want to just log into Bitbucket, because that uses an Atlassian password, I have to now enter the 6 digit codes for both Atlassian login and then again for Bitbucket, despite only having a single username/password.  This is SO DUMB.  It should be trivial for Atlassian's two factor authentication to forward something during the Bitbucket loading that let's me skip two factor the second time.  This happens for EVERYONE in my company. And EVERYONE is complaining about it constantly.
fields.summary: Two Factor needs 2 codes if required for Atlassian(Jira/Confluence) and Bitbucket

PR is visible

h3. Actual Result
PR is not visible
fields.summary: Pull request browser script error

fields.description:
Hi there,\\
After reading the [Visual Studio 2019 preview 3 release notes|https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/releases/2019/release-notes-preview] (which is due to be released on the 2nd of April 2019) specifically these two points:

* Sign in, browse, and one-click clone or connect to your hosted repositories from Azure DevOps through the start window.
* Install extensions for other source control hosts to view repositories owned by you and your organization.

It appears that Microsoft is no longer going to provide BitBucket integration and that developers such as Atlassian will need to write their own Visual Studio extension.  Is there any plan for Atlassian to develop an extension for Visual Studio that will allow repositories to be browsed, and provide integration with JIRA to associate commits/branches with JIRA tickets etc?  If there is, what is the timeline for releasing it?
fields.summary: Visual Studio 2019 Extension now required
Return token expiration hint for LFS download links

fields.description:
There's nowhere to see all notification on bitbucket.org!

The only way to get notification is via email (or integrated app like Slack/Hipchat). This is not useful, since our email will be floated with a lot of emails.

On Github, there's a notification center, where we see all the comments on issues/PR, which is very helpful to see what's updated.

I hope this is added to Bitbucket as well.
fields.summary: Be able to see all notification on the web

fields.description:
Currently, if clicking on the wiki commit history the URL will redirect to for example:

* https://bitbucket.org/<teamname>/<reponame>/commits/<commithash>

The correct URL redirection should be:

* https://bitbucket.org/<teamname>/<reponame>/wiki/commits/<commithash>
fields.summary: Wiki commit history url is redirected to normal commit url
Markdown: Bitbucket issue-tracker CSS causes inline backticked code to appear above regular font baseline

fields.description: When a cache upload fails at the end of a step (for example because it exceeds the 1GB limit) the log message that should indicate the cause of the failure is missing.
fields.summary: The log message describing the cause of a cache upload failure is missing

fields.description:
Hey\\
We are using with PR in part of the development process\\
I would like to see all the changeset between branches before i merge

i'm not sure it can happend in bitbucket cloud

please advise

Thanks
fields.summary: bitbucket cloud show changeset

fields.description:
h3. STEPS
# Open a repo
# Go to the Branches page
# Click on the Build status icon

h3. ACTUAL
A popup window appears

!2985384943-Screenshot%20from%202019-02-14%2011-22-08.png|thumbnail!

h3. EXPECT
Clicking the icon opens a new tab on the build site (ex: the buidl page on Codeship)

h3. NOTES
Up until a week or so ago, the expected behavior was the actual behavior. Was a bug introduced?
fields.summary: Build status icon on the Branches page no longer links to the Build Tool

fields.description:
Is there any API to get the tree of a repository?\\
I use the internal API (https://bitbucket.org/!api/internal/repositories/[user]/[repo]/tree/[commit]/) for now but that feels unstable\\
related: BCLOUD-8316
fields.summary: API to get repository tree
Bug on Apache Mina is causing SSH clone to fail.

fields.description: BB-8925 was marked as invalid but it is still an issue. Nested lists are not rendered properly. Please re-open BB-8925 and sort this mess out.
fields.summary: Markdown: Nested lists not working (issue BB-8925) is not invalid

fields.description: Similar to what was done for Jira/Confluence sites (https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/user-provisioning-959305316.html), it would be great to have this same feature for Bitbucket Cloud accounts as well.
fields.summary: Implement user provisioning for Bitbucket Cloud repositories & groups

fields.description:
The Deployment variables functionality was recently added as per BCLOUD-13474

However, there is no API endpoint to support that functionality, it's not possible to programmatically read and create a new environment variable using the API V2.
fields.summary: Add deployment variables API endpoint

fields.description: When you push commit with same name like your last commit, approves does not disappear.
fields.summary: Approve does not disappear after commit

fields.description: For teams, it could be a useful feature to be able to set default reviewers and branch permissions for all the repositories in a team account. In case they want to add the same branch permissions and reviewers to all the repositories within the team account, where they have more than 10+ repositories, it is time-consuming as they need to open the repositories one-by-one.
fields.summary: Being able to set default reviewers and branch permission in bulk for team accounts

fields.description:
Good morning everyone.

Nothing happens when we try to make "clone in sourcetree".

Can you help us, please?
fields.summary: CLONE IN SOURCETREE

fields.description:
Hi, when I run "git clone https://snapworks@bitbucket.org/snapweb/sha-snaphomework.git" command, it shows me following error

Cloning into 'sha-snaphomework'...\\
fatal: unable to access 'https://snapworks@bitbucket.org/snapweb/sha-snaphomework.git/': Failed to connect to bitbucket.org port 443: Network is unreachable
fields.summary: Unable to clone my new created repository

fields.description: Currently user will received all email notification within the Pull request. However, it's not available for the user to only select to received only a specific new pull request created only.
fields.summary: Email notification for new Pull Request created only

fields.description: The login screen was changed so that the password input is hidden. This breaks every desktop password manager so that they can't perform "auto-type". Now it takes 4 steps to login where it used to take only 1.
fields.summary: The new login screen, breaks password managers.

fields.description:
Hi,

Just cleaned up our groups repository yesterday and the bitbucket repository size tracker hasn't caught up yet.

My '''' git count-objects --v ''' shows a size-pack of: 83711

Could someone run ''' git gc ''' from your end on https://bitbucket.org/medtronicplc/mitgai

Looks like that is what fixed these other occurrences: BCLOUD-10375

Thanks
fields.summary: Repository Size Discrepancy After Cleaning

fields.description: I have former team members that I would like to anonymize. This feature appears to be available only in server at this time. I am a cloud user and would like the same feature.
fields.summary: Enable Anonymize user feature in BB Cloud

fields.description: For large pull requests (100+ files), only the first 100 files are shown. This is not an issue on the old pull request view.
fields.summary: New PR only shows first 100 files

fields.description:
Currently, if you have more than 10 activities in a pull request, the new PR UI only shows the 10 most recent activities.

It would be best if we can show older activities instead of only 10.

This is because older activities are essentials for users to view.
fields.summary: UI: New PR Shows only 10 most recent Activities

fields.description: When trying to click the media icon in the toolbar for editing the default pull request, nothing happens and i am not presented with a dialog to upload an image
fields.summary: Cant add image to the default pull request

fields.description:
To reproduce:

* create a comment on any commit in Bitbucket
* tag a user by their name
* if the user has First name and last name populated when you case your comment, his name will appear in the view
* if you click on Edit the comment, if the user name was FirstName space Last name, anything after the space will be dropped and wrong user will be tagged.

Temp Workaround:  before saving the comment after the edit, remove the user tagged previously to avoid having a wrong user tagged and start typing the correct user again and select him on dropdown prompt
fields.summary: Editing an exiting comment with a user tagged will clear anything after the space, thus making wrong user tagged

fields.description:
I'd love to be able to use the evolve extension. It seems that it should work: BCLOUD-6710 so I tried to enable its use in Bitbucket Labs ("Enables Mercurial evolution support").

However, the obsolescence markers are not sent in the remote repository in Bitbucket.

See https://bitbucket.org/paugier/repo_test_evolve_fork

I use the most recent versions of mercurial and hg-evolve, installed with {{pip2 install mercurial hg-evolve -U --user}}.

{code}
hg --version
Mercurial Distributed SCM (version 4.9)
...

python2 -c "import hgext3rd.evolve as e; print(e.__version__)"
8.4.0
{code}
fields.summary: Evolve Mercurial extension: obsolescence markers not exchanged with https

fields.description:
I just discovered that anonymous users can see issues I create along with my full name. Any chance you could obscure those?

Example URL (view in incognito): BCLOUD-18148

If you navigate to https://bitbucket.org/michaelbean/, you'll see that I have set my profile to make my  "identity a mystery", but exposing my name doesn't keep it a mystery.
fields.summary: PII: Issue tracker exposes my name to public

fields.description:
I tested on both a remote server and my local machine. Completely different locations.

Bottle-neck seems to be our account or Bitbucket in general.

{code}\\
$ time git fetch\\
real	0m1.382s\\
user	0m0.035s\\
sys	0m0.006s\\
{code}

{code}\\
$ time git fetch\\
git fetch  0.08s\\
user 0.03s\\
system 2% cpu\\
total 5.189\\
{code}

They seem small, but they are hinting at something.

Filing this under "SSH" because there is no "git" component.
fields.summary: git fetch taking abnormally long time to run

fields.description: there is issue with show more button inside repo
fields.summary: Issue Show More button

fields.description:
Bitbucket reports incorrect commit and pull request build status in case the same commit is built more than once, e.g. the first build is failed, but the second one is successful.

Here is an example:

Commit build status is failed

!2197520724-bb_commit_status_1.png|thumbnail!

... but there is a successful build that occurred later on

!4285078212-bb_commit_status_2.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Incorrect build status of a commit that is built more than once

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Some developers often need to type strings like @some-text in their commit and pull request messages. When the text displays, this results in unwanted @ mentions.

h3. Suggested Solution
Users would like to be able to disable @ mentions feature, on a per mentioned user basis.\\
I.e. specify certain strings that they wouldn't like to result in @ mentions.

h3. Workaround
Current workaround is by writing the @ mention in a code block with backticks, like {{@some-text}}
fields.summary: Allow admins to disable @mention for specific strings/usernames

fields.description:
I've also issued this in CoreOS:\\
https://github.com/coreos/bugs/issues/2549

We have some tests which involve POSIX-timer funcionality. Today those tests started to hang. It seems like the kernel of the Pipelines infrastructure has been upgraded and now includes a regression, as reported in the above issue.
fields.summary: Pipelines with tests base on POSIX timers are failing
